so Everett Rogers wrote a book called
diffusion of innovations in 1962 just a
smidge before I was born and he coined
this analogy for how new technologies or
new solutions or new services are
adopted and he called it his innovation
adoption curve
and essentially it says when a new
technology or capability comes to the
market only a very small handful of
people adopt that and it's a bell curve
so it's a distribution and that first
wave of people who adopt that
bleeding-edge technology if you like he
coins the innovators and then his
momentum picks up and visibility picks
up and people become more aware of the
technology more people start to take on
that new service at new capability so
they call the early adopters and as the
technology matures and it becomes more
broad in its reach we then have the
early majority and then the top of that
bell curve is sometimes colloquially
known as the tipping point and when the
market hits that point from there on
there are more people than not who are
adopting that new technology or that new
capability and then as we start to move
through that technology adoption wave we
had the late majority and at the very
end the laggards and it would be unfair
to turn the public sector as Lagarde's
because they are not like ours however

Amazon flywheel is a concept that talks
about as we go to our wholesalers to buy

we negotiate an even better price point
we paid less this time around than what
we paid last time around because we
bought the wholesale goods at a lower

I mean so we get an influx of new

the prices again
and then more customers jump in and then

spinned
there's a click-through agreement if you

Explorer that enable you to produce
